5c38e60b507ec46c:
% The categories in Constants include people and jobs. We use different variables P and J to represent people and jobs.
% We assign a job J to a person P, where P belongs to people and J belongs to jobs.
assign(P, J)
642200479f1951f3:
% Task 1. Define the constants in each category.
people("Roberta"; "Thelma"; "Steve"; "Pete").
jobs("chef"; "guard"; "nurse"; "telephone operator"; "police officer"; "teacher"; "actor"; "boxer").
% Task 2. For each person P, they hold exactly 2 jobs J.
{assign(P, J): jobs(J)}=2 :- people(P).
c8beb8f033692ae9:
% 5. The job of nurse is held by a male.
P="Steve" or P="Pete" :- assign(P,J), J="nurse".

% 6. The husband of the chef is the telephone operator, which means the chef is a female and the telephone operator is a male.
P="Roberta" or P="Thelma" :- assign(P,J), J="chef".
P="Steve" or P="Pete" :- assign(P,J), J="telephone operator".

% 7. Roberta is not a boxer.
J!="boxer" :- assign(P,J), P="Roberta".

% 8. Pete has no education past the ninth grade. (Three jobs teacher, nurse, and police officer require higher education.)
{J="teacher"; J="nurse"; J="police officer"}=0 :- assign(P,J), P="Pete".

% 9. Roberta, the chef, and the police officer went golfing together, meaning they are different people.
P1!=P2 :- assign(P1,J1), assign(P2,J2), assign(P3,J3), P1="Roberta", J2="chef", J3="police officer".
P2!=P3 :- assign(P1,J1), assign(P2,J2), assign(P3,J3), P1="Roberta", J2="chef", J3="police officer".
P1!=P3 :- assign(P1,J1), assign(P2,J2), assign(P3,J3), P1="Roberta", J2="chef", J3="police officer".

% 10.1 The same job cannot be assigned to different people.
{P1=P2}=0 :- assign(P1,J), assign(P2,J), P1!=P2.

% 10.2 Roberta is a female.
% 10.3 Thelma is a female.
% 10.4 Steve is a male.
% 10.5 Pete is a male.
% These constraints are already considered in the constraints above.

% 10.6 The actor is a male.
P="Steve" or P="Pete" :- assign(P,J), J="actor".
